data.description: Morphological characteristics of the world's languages. Introduction to theoretical approaches to morphology. Interaction between morphology and syntax; morphology and phonology.
data.title: MORPHOLOGY

data.description: Advanced directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.
data.title: INDEPENDENT READING

data.description: Advanced morphological theory.
data.title: ADVANCED MORPHOLOGY

data.description: An introduction to elementary skills in production and comprehension of American Sign Language (ASL), with a communicative focus. Basics of ASL vocabulary, structure, and grammar, and the North American manual alphabet. Develop basic conversational abilities, culturally appropriate behaviors, and learn about the culture and history of Deaf communities.
data.title: AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE 1

data.description: Analysis and formal statement of phonological systems; problems and methods of phonological theory.
data.title: PHONOLOGY

data.description: Collection and analysis of morphological, syntactic, and semantic data from a particular language, using one or more speakers as consultants.
data.title: FIELD METHODS II

data.description: Collection and analysis of phonetic, phonological, and morphological data from a particular language, using one or more speakers as consultants.
data.title: FIELD METHODS I

data.description: Critical examination of selected issues in linguistics.
data.title: SEMINAR

data.description: Develop comprehension and production abilities in American Sign Language (ASL). Recognition and demonstration of more sophisticated grammatical features of ASL, focusing on increasing fluency and accuracy. Develop cultural awareness of the Deaf communities of the world.
data.title: AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE 2

data.description: Directed study projects as arranged with a faculty member.
data.title: DIRECTED STUDY

data.description: Elementary theory and practical work in phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax, with attention to formal grammar.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO LINGUISTICS: DESCRIPTIVE AND THEORETICAL

data.description: Elementary theory and practical work in phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax, with attention to formal grammar.
data.title: HUMAN LANGUAGE

data.description: Focuses on language and its culture, example topics include: extinction and revival, language and nationhood, how widely and deeply languages differ, language and worldview, writing systems and literacy, language discrimination and inequality.
data.title: GLOBAL LANGUAGE ISSUES

data.description: For millennia, the place we now call Wisconsin has been home to countless languages and dialects: Indigenous languages, immigrant/refugee languages and English. How and when did people learn English and when and why did they begin to speak only English? How has English developed in distinctive ways here? Do hands-on, original research to answer these and related questions about English and other languages past and present in Wisconsin. Examine social and historical issues and issues of linguistic structure, drawing on local histories, archival data, Census records and audio recordings, with opportunities to do fieldwork in communities across the state and the region.
data.title: LANGUAGE IN WISCONSIN

data.description: Grammatical theory; types of elements and processes usable in syntactic description of various sorts.
data.title: SYNTAX

data.description: In-depth exploration of a particular topic in linguistics. Training in data collection methodologies. Experience gathering, organizing, and analyzing linguistic data as part of a supervised research project.
data.title: CAPSTONE IN LINGUISTICS

data.description: In-depth study of all components of the grammar of a language.
data.title: STRUCTURE OF A LANGUAGE

data.description: Introduction and overview of the linguistics of sign languages, signing communities, and perceptions of deaf people and sign languages. Topics include: the grammar of sign languages, their use in signing communities, patterns in the transmission and acquisition of sign languages, and the emergence of new sign languages.
data.title: SIGN LANGUAGE LINGUISTICS

data.description: Introduction to sociolinguistics through study of a particular topic. Focuses on how language is shaped by social factors such as gender, ethnicity, education, social status, and geographic location.
data.title: TOPICS IN SOCIOLINGUISTICS

data.description: Introduction to theories of variation among world languages, focusing on syntactic phenomena.
data.title: GRAMMATICAL VARIABILITY OF LANGUAGE

data.description: Linguistic and sociolinguistic change in English from its beginnings to the present.
data.title: HISTORY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE

data.description: Meaning in natural languages, relationship between syntax and semantics, compositional semantics.
data.title: SEMANTICS

data.description: Overview of native languages of North America, including topics such as history, distribution, diversity, government policy, language endangerment, elaboration of cultural domains, language and worldview, speech styles, language structure (phonology, morphology, grammatical categories), performance (narrative, song), writing systems.
data.title: SURVEY OF NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN LANGUAGES

data.description: Professionalization activities for linguists, including writing and publishing, submitting abstracts to conferences, and creating CVs.
data.title: RESEARCH METHODS AND MATERIALS

data.description: Research in connection with the doctoral thesis.
data.title: THESIS

data.description: Study of a particular topic in linguistics.
data.title: TOPICS IN LINGUISTICS

data.description: The relationship of language as a communication system to the culture transmitted by it. Principle problems in the interrelations of language and nonlinguistic human behavior.
data.title: LANGUAGE AND CULTURE

data.description: Theories of phonology, and advanced phonological description.
data.title: PHONOLOGICAL THEORIES

data.description: Theories of syntax, and syntactic description. The relation of syntax to semantics, and other aspects of linguistic theory.
data.title: SYNTACTIC THEORIES

data.description: Understanding language change; relation of variation and change to formal properties of human language; consideration of linguistic typology, basic concepts and methods of diachronic analysis. Topics include: language classification and reconstruction; language and social identity, geography, and power; language contact; registers; writing systems.
data.title: HISTORICAL LINGUISTICS
